The goalie still has to bend his knees and then jump. There is also the curve, and you have to take gravity into account.

Sorry Salman but I think you messed up. How can you say the goalie has .13s to make a decision on where to jump if you already assumed he was on the hypotenuse when making the calculations? He couldn't change directions by then.

too many assumptions.. this cannot be applied to football.. its kind of embarassing that you apply the pythagoras theorem for something COMPLETELY USELESS!! there are so many things to apply maths (statistics) on such as individual player performance or team performance but this is nonsense

But this isn't 100% accurate. You're assuming that a) the ball doesn't accelerate/deccelerate b) you're forgetting alot of the human factors. So while this is as close as you can get, it is obviously also incorrect. Sorry lads. Some things can't be measured with simple mathematics because it takes more than that. General physics have to be involved in these type of questions as well... :) Great idea though, I'd love to see how a goalkeeper reacts when a freekick is taken, that might be a little bit harder though considering the ball could bend or like I said before (accelerate/deccelerate).

Not only reaction time, also the processing time for the keeper to judge the side of the ball is going. Human conventional reaction tests are usually about reacting to something moving or lamp lighting, in which no processing of direction is needed.

The real question is what if Sergio Ramos was taking the penalty?

You can just divide the ball speed in 88 ft/sec by 4 to get the jump speed of 22 ft/sec.  It is easy to spot that 15 is one fourth of 60.  No need to do the same calculation again.  That is what I think is lacking in the American way of teaching.  The don't encourage students to apply logic and spot patterns.  An extra few seconds saved could mean a lot during a test.

Sal, you could also make a video showing a quicker way to find a distance in 3-D when you know three orthogonal distances.  (36^2 + 12^2 + 8^2)^(1/2) = 38.78 . You can consider all three dimensions at once, and this idea could have its own video which I am sure people would love to see!

Question: wouldn't it be better if the goalkeeper reaches on a direction perpendicular to the ball trajectory, or in this case the 38.78ft distance, or 37.95 ft distance, basically the goalkeeper has to jumpp perpendicular on the plane defined by the penalty kick point and the  2 ends of the goal side pole ?!
